text: next around this time of year smog in
delhi usually becomes a big problem but
this year there might be some measures
not previously seen officials are ready
to impose a complete lockdown to fight
worsening air pollution schools have
already been closed for a week and civil
servants have been ordered to work from
home well joining me now uh in delhi is
our correspondent rajini vijayanathan hi
regina good to see you so this seems you
know it's funny this idea of lockdowns
which just a couple of years ago would
be absolutely draconian we are now very
used to because of covid19 and
potentially on its way now for air
pollution
that's right and many people here in
delhi are have also been for a long time
used to wearing face masks not just for
covid but to protect people from the
dangerous uh foul filthy air that is
outside i mean i'm lucky enough to be
indoors at the moment that there are so
many people in this city who have to go
outside for their work now uh the levels
of air pollution at the moment are lower
than the last few days but in the last
couple of weeks they were as high as 10
times the recommended limit according to
the world health organization in
particular concern is over levels of
what they call pm 2.5 and they're the
tiny particles that you can breathe in
and they can sort of stay lodged in your
lungs they can lead to respiratory
illnesses
and serious health conditions and i mean
just telling you personally lewis what
it's like it's one of those things
that's a stealth thing here in delhi you
sometimes feel you've got a really
really bad headache you can taste sort
of metallic uh in your metallic sort of
taste in your throat and you do feel
light-headed at times and it's it's
there everywhere and that's the concern
but i think the thing that really is one
of the questions many people here in
delhi ask is why isn't anything changing
this isn't the first time i've reported
on this for bbc world and it probably
won't be the last
yeah that's the interesting thing isn't
it because this was a court uh order
effectively a couple of days ago wasn't
it saying something needs to be done
here for the air quality index equal to
so bad but some of the questions even if
a lockdown does come in what actual
difference can it make in the long term
it's probably worth uh reminding our
viewers lewis what people say is causing
this deadly smog in the air now this
toxic smog i should say now there are a
few factors that people say are to blame
now one of the
main factors people say is the farmers
in the neighboring states who burn their
crop stubble to clear their fields at
the end of the year for a new season and
that can produce huge amounts of smoke
but officials here in delhi say it's not
just that it's also
the traffic fumes industrial emissions
and people always talk about the fumes
from diwali fireworks in the aftermath
from the festival of diwali and other
festivals that happen at this time of
year a lot of people argue and debate
over what the causes are but i think one
of the uh you know ongoing uh challenges
is what the solutions are so you've got
the delhi government now saying that
children should have online classes for
the next week you've also got civil
servants as you say louis being told to
stay at home and you've got some
construction work that's been suspended
for the next few days but that isn't a
long-term lasting solution and it was a
supreme court hearing uh at the weekend
discussing this situation and one
official said that living in delhi and
breathing in this air is equivalent to
smoking 20 cigarettes a day and that
applies to newborns as well so that's
how stark and serious this is but the
challenge is that we keep having these
conversations and many people here say
what is going to change
yeah that's interesting regina can i be
cheeky while i've got you here um just
wanted to get um the reaction i suppose
to cop 26 of course the big climate
change summit just wrapped up here in
the uk in glasgow at the very last
second india accused of watering down
the language in relation to coal and
fossil fuels what's the reaction to that
being
well you're saying that other countries
are saying that india is accused of
watering it down but here in india the
reaction has been is that india has come
back from the cop summit with a success
story that's what india's environment
minister was saying in the wake of the
summit now for india
it's always been about balancing
economic growth in the country with
ensuring that environmental challenges
are met at the same time now the indian
government has promised to go net zero
by 2070 and says it is aggressively
moving towards solar alternatives but
coal is still a very big part of the
power equation here in india coal power
is some 70 percent of the country's
energy at the moment so going from 70 to
zero is going to take time and i think
that's the narrative that the indian
side takes away from the cop summit and
indian officials say we are doing things
to try and turn towards cleaner sources
of energy but indians also say look at
the west you've been making promises for
a long time but you'll know we're near
reducing or eliminating your fossil fuel
use so you know look at your own uh
issues and emissions before you start
pointing the finger here so it is kind
of different narrative lewis with people
here saying actually it's been a success
when it comes to cop
interesting stuff great to talk to you
thanks for genie
